newsitem.title: JAPAN: BOJ's Aug dollar purchases estimated at $1.75 bln.
newsitem.headline: BOJ's Aug dollar purchases estimated at $1.75 bln.

text.p: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) bought an estimated $1.75 billion in currency market intervention in August, up sharply from $567 million in July, bankers said.
BOJ data, released on Monday, showed that capital outlays from the government special foreign exchange account to the private sector totalled 187 billion yen in August.
The figure consists mostly of yen payments from the government foreign exchange account to the private sector, mainly commercial banks.
Those yen payments are a result of dollar-buying intervention against the yen by the BOJ, bankers said.
The August figures include the last two trading days of July but not the last two business days of August, as currency settlements are made two days after transactions.
The Ministry of Finance, which manages the foreign exchange account, raises yen cash for intervention by issuing special financing bills (FBs) for foreign exchange operations.
The FBs are also used to convert dollar-denominated income gains on the government's external reserves into yen. Outstanding FBs as of August 31 totalled 27.76 trillion yen.
The dollar moved in a range of 106.35-108.59 yen in Tokyo's foreign exchange market in August.
